journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Subcooled boiling heat transfer modelling for internal combustion engine applications

contrib-group.aff: School of Energy and Power Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *School of Energy and Power Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430074, People’s Republic of China. email: rhhuang@mail.hust.edu.cn

abstract.p: Any boiling-based strategy in developing cooling systems of internal combustion (IC) engines requires an accurate prediction of coolant-side heat transfer. The computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulation incorporating subcooled boiling models is an effective approach for such analyses. However, most of the existing models are developed in some special flow and boiling conditions differing from that in IC engines, which inevitably leads to great discrepancies when they are directly applied to CFD analyses inside IC engine cooling galleries.

A modified model with adjustable parameters is proposed based on the division description method in this paper. The predicted heat fluxes by different boiling models are compared against experimental data obtained in a cooling gallery simulator passage. The results indicate that a higher precision can be obtained by the modified model in predicting the boiling heat flux over a wide range of operating conditions as long as the parameters are accurately corrected. The performance of the modified model for practical IC engine applications is further assessed and the results show that the computational error is effectively reduced due to the incorporation of the modified model in the conjugate heat transfer simulation of the cylinder head and cylinder head cooling gallery.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Boiling is an extremely advantageous mechanism, due to its ability to extract higher rates of heat transfer for only small increases in surface temperatures. A considerable reduction in fuel consumption and exhaust emission would be expected if a boiling regime is properly utilized in the development of modern cooling systems of internal combustion (IC) engines [1]. In order to achieve controllable boiling over a wide range of operating conditions, a detailed flow and heat transfer analysis in the cooling gallery is essential. An effective approach for such analyses is the CFD simulation incorporating boiling models [2–4].

The heat transfer characteristic during subcooled flow boiling has been studied thoroughly [5, 6]. The heat flux versus the wall temperature with a constant liquid subcooling degree is shown in Fig. 1. The boiling curves displayed respectively by the solid line and dotted line represent two different flowrates. Initially the heat transfer is by a single-phase (SP) convective mode, where the heat transfer coefficient (HTC) is mainly dependent on the local flow condition. As the wall superheat increases, a change in the slope of the SP line at point B indicates the onset of nucleate boiling (ONB), from which the heat transfer goes into the partially developed boiling (PDB) region. The heat transfer in the PDB region is basically dominated by two effects: the convective heat transfer due to the motion of the bulk liquid; and the nucleate boiling heat transfer associated with the bubble nucleation and departure. The contribution of the nucleate boiling heat transfer is enhanced while the convective component is reduced as the wall superheat further increases. At a certain location C, the convective heat transfer is totally suppressed, indicating the onset of fully developed boiling (OFDB). The heat transfer in the fully developed boiling (FDB) region is merely by nucleate boiling mode, where the heat flux is almost independent of the local flow condition. This is evident from the final merging of the boiling curves with different velocities. At present, two kinds of boiling models are utilized for engineering applications to predict the heat flux during subcooled flow boiling, which are described in the following sections.

caption.p: Boiling curves during subcooled flow boiling

sec.title: 1.1 Superposition method
sec.p: The linear superposition method was originally introduced by Chen [7], who assumed the total wall heat flux qw to be additively composed of a convective component qconv and a nucleate boiling component qboil during saturated flow boiling

where F represents an enhancement of convective heat transfer and is associated with the local mass fraction of the vapor phase, and S represents a flow-induced suppression of nucleate boiling heat transfer and is commonly modelled as a function of the Reynolds number Re. Chen’s model was later applied to subcooled boiling conditions, where the effect of a vapour–liquid two-phase flow on the convective heat transfer was neglected by setting the enhancement factor F to 1 [8].
The asymptotic superposition model was proposed by Steiner and Taborek [9] to predict the flow boiling heat transfer based on a power-additive addition of the two components, described as
where m is an empirical constant to be determined by experiment data and F=1 is applied to subcooled boiling conditions.

The superposition method offers relatively simple additive forms of the nucleate boiling heat transfer and convective terms. The correct asymptotes are provided at the transition to the non-boiling regime, where the nucleate boiling component becomes zero and only the convective component remains. Thus the linear and asymptotic superposition concepts have been adopted by several other researchers using different submodels for the nucleate boiling heat flux qboil and various correlations for factors S or m during subcooled flow boiling [6, 10–11]. However, the boiling heat transfer characteristic in the subcooled boiling condition is considerably different from that in saturated boiling. The previous investigations [6, 12] indicate that it is difficult to obtain high calculation accuracy in the whole subcooled boiling region by a single correlation based on the superposition method.

sec.title: 1.2 Division description method
sec.p: Boiling models based on the division description method were developed to describe better the heat transfer characteristic during subcooled flow boiling. In these models, the convective heat flux and boiling curves in PDB and FDB regions as well as the ONB and OFDB points are described separately. Numerous models were proposed on that basis [5, 12–13], among which Kandlikar’s model [5] was later utilized for subcooled boiling researches inside IC engine cooling galleries [14].

In this model, traditional convective heat transfer correlations are used to predict the heat flux in the SP region qw,SP and saturated flow boiling correlations are adopted to describe the FDB curve qw,FDB.
The heat fluxes of the ONB point qONB and OFDB point qOFDB are obtained by the following equations

where k is the thermal conductivity, λ is the latent heat of vaporization, ρ is the density, σ is the surface tension, Tsat is the saturation temperature, subscripts l and g, ONB, and OFDB relate to the liquid and gas, the ONB value, and the OFDB value respectively, and qF is determined by the intersection of the extension of the SP line A–B–F and the FDB curve E–F, as shown in Fig. 1. Then the wall temperature at the ONB point TONB and OFDB point TOFDB can be calculated respectively from the SP line and the FDB curve.
In the PDB region, an exponential function based on the wall superheat ΔTsat is used to predict the heat flux qw,PDB, described as
where parameters a and b are identified by the ONB point and OFDB point, and exponent n is a curve fit factor related to the wall heat flux.

Although a large number of boiling models have been proposed in the past for engineering applications, it would inevitably lead to great discrepancies when they are directly applied to CFD analyses inside IC engine cooling galleries, since most of these models rely on a good deal of empirical parameters developed in some special flow and boiling conditions that are different from that in IC engines.

The objective of this work is to improve the ability of predicting the subcooled boiling heat transfer inside IC engine cooling galleries. In the present paper, a modified model with adjustable parameters is proposed based on the division description method within the CFD framework, and the precision of the modified model applied in a cooling gallery simulator passage as well as a practical IC engine is investigated.

sec.title: 2 Subcooled Boiling Heat Transfer Modelling
sec.p: Several modifications are performed on Kandlikar’s division description method [5] to adapt it to CFD analyses in geometrically complex cooling galleries of IC engines, and to improve its precision further in both FDB and PDB regions.

sec.title: 2.1 FDB region
sec.p: In the FDB region, the heat transfer is dominated by nucleating boiling with little contribution from the convective heat transfer. The heat transfer characteristic in the FDB region is similar to that in pool boiling. Rohsenow’s correlation [15] is used to predict the heat flux in the present paper, as no geometry-dependent parameters are required by the correlation, which can be described as

where μ is the dynamic viscosity, Cp is the specific heat, Pr is the Prandtl number, g is the gravity constant, and Cs and γ are adjustable parameters used to describe the impact of various physical factors such as the wall roughness, metal/fluid combination, passage dimensions, and heating process, which have been proved to have a great effect on the heat transfer characteristic during subcooled flow boiling [9, 11, 14, 16].

Since the Rohsenow correlation was originally proposed by adjusting model parameters based on experiment data obtained in saturated pool boiling, if it is directly applied to predict the flow boiling heat transfer in subcooled boiling conditions inside IC engines, it would consequentially lead to great discrepancies. In order to describe the FDB curve in the cooling gallery more precisely, it is recommended that Cs and γ in equation (6) are corrected, based on experiment data obtained in cooling gallery simulator rigs [1, 6, 14], which were designed specifically to simulate the subcooled flow boiling that appeared in IC engines.

sec.title: 2.2 ONB and OFDB points
sec.p: The ONB point is a mark of the transition from the SP region to the PDB region, while the OFDB point is a mark of the transition from the PDB region to the FDB region, as shown in Fig. 1. Equations (3) and (4) are used to determine the locations of the ONB point and OFDB point without any modification. However, the wall function widely used in CFD analyses is adopted to calculate the local convective heat flux instead, which is inferred semi-empirically from the near-wall velocity profiles and turbulence intensities, described as

where T* is the non-dimensional temperature parameter, y* is the non-dimensional distance parameter, y is the distance from the wall to the cell centre, Ke is the turbulence kinetic energy, Prt is the turbulent Prandtl number, κ is the von Karman constant and is equal to 0.4187, Cu and E are empirical constants and are equal to 0.09 and 9.793 respectively, and subscripts w and p relate to the wall and near-wall cell.
The local convective HTC is obtained by the following equation
where Tb is the temperature of the bulk flow.

In several previous studies [2, 4], the local variables required by boiling models, such as the bulk velocity and the bulk temperature, were taken out from the near-wall cell in CFD analyses. However, most of the constitutive correlations were derived from flow boiling experimental data obtained in regular tubes in terms of mean velocities and mean temperatures. When the mean values are replaced by the ones from the near-wall cell, it would inevitably lead to grid-dependent results in CFD analyses. In the present work, the non-dimensional temperature T* at a specified non-dimensional distance y* is used instead of the temperature in the near-wall cell to ensure grid invariant solutions in CFD analyses, and the bulk temperature in equation (10) is obtained by setting the non-dimensional distance y* to 250, which has been found to be appropriate in the previous investigation [17].
Thus the heat fluxes and temperatures of the ONB point and OFDB point can be calculated by combining equations (3), (4), and (6) to (10) in CFD analyses.

sec.title: 2.3 PDB region
sec.p: The PDB region is identified as the region between the ONB point and the OFDB point, as shown in Fig. 1. The heat transfer in the PDB region is considered as a combination of convective heat transfer and nucleate boiling heat transfer, and interpolation methods were always adopted to construct the PDB curve. An exponential function based on the temperature difference between the wall and the bulk liquid, instead of the wall superheat described in equation (5), is utilized to predict the heat flux in the PDB region in the present paper
where parameters a, b, and n are determined by the locations of the ONB point, the OFDB point, and the local SP line as follows
These conditions, when applied to equation (11), result in the following new forms

Thus, parameters a, b, and n can be obtained by iterative calculation with equations (15) to (17) in CFD analyses, and the boiling heat flux in the PDB region can be calculated immediately by equation (11) with a given wall temperature.

The experimental data form Steiner and Taborek’s work [9] with R11 as the coolant in a typical subcooled flow boiling condition was utilized for a comparison of the PDB curve predicted by the modified model (11) and Kandlikar’s model [5]. Two groups of data with different velocities are shown in Fig. 2. For the high-velocity group, the SP line was constructed by the low superheat data and the ONB point was identified by the point where the slope of the SP line started to change, while the FDB curve was corrected by the high superheat data and the OFDB point was identified by the point where the boiling curves with different velocities finally merged. The PDB curve obtained by the modified model with the dashed line contrasting to Kandlikar’s boiling model displayed by the dotted line is shown in Fig. 2. It can be seen that the modified model assures a smooth transition of the slope of the boiling curve at the ONB point, relating the increase rate of the flow boiling heat transfer in the PDB region with the convective HTC in the SP region. On the contrary, the PDB curve predicted by Kandlikar’s model is totally independent of the SP line, resulting in great discrepancies in the low superheat region. Thus a more reasonable description of the heat transfer characteristic can be obtained by the modified model in the PDB region, which is typically met in liquid cooling systems of IC engines.

caption.p: Comparisons of the partially developed boiling curve between Kandlikar’s model and the modified model

sec.p: In addition, since no geometry-dependent parameters are required by the modified model, it can be directly used to predict the flow boiling heat transfer in geometrically complex cooling galleries of IC engines.

sec.title: 3 Comparisons of Model Predictions with Experiments
sec.p: The precision of boiling models including the modified model described by equations (3), (4), and (6) to (17), Kandlikar’s model [5], and Chen’s model [7] are compared within the CFD framework by validations against experimental data from Steiner etal.’s work [6] in a horizontal channel with pure water as the coolant.

sec.title: 3.1 Validation case
sec.p: The experimental data were obtained in a cooling gallery simulator passage. As shown in Fig. 3, the flow channel has a rectangular cross-section of 40 mm × 30 mm. The fluid is asymmetrically heated by an aluminium alloy surface located at the bottom of the horizontal channel with dimensions of 60 mm × 10 mm. All the experimental data are divided into six groups at different bulk velocities and operating pressures, which are summarized in Table 1. These conditions correspond to a Reynolds number range from 5523 to 129 246.

caption.p: The flow domain and calculation meshes in the cooling gallery simulator passage

sec.p: Computations were performed on the generic CFD code Fluent. The fluid flow was considered to be fully turbulent under the experimental conditions outlined above and was modelled using the k–ε turbulence model in conjunction with the wall function approach. For each case, a three-dimensional mesh containing hexagonal elements was generated covering the entire flow domain. A uniform distribution of the inlet velocity and temperature as well as the outlet pressure was defined according to the measured bulk data and a uniform temperature distribution was defined in the heating surface, while other walls were assumed to be adiabatic. The meshes of the cases at different velocities as well as the corresponding y* distributions in the cross-section in the middle of the heating surface are shown in Fig. 3. Sensitivity tests were performed to confirm that the computational results were not affected by the assumed boundary conditions, such as the inlet velocity profile and turbulent intensity as well as the outlet pressure profile. The boiling models were incorporated by user defined functions (UDFs) into the CFD package in order to read necessary local variables and further calculate the flow boiling heat flux.

In order to estimate the reasonableness of introducing adjustable parameters in predicting the flow boiling heat transfer in subcooled boiling conditions, Cs and γ in equation (6) were obtained by correlating the experimental data in group 1 at an extremely low velocity of 0.05 m/s and were applied afterwards to other operating conditions. Hence Cs=0.0248 and γ=0.613 were finally adopted by the modified model.

sec.title: 3.2 Results and discussion
sec.p: The comparisons between predictions and experimental data in each group are shown in Figs 4(a), (b), and (c) and Figs 5(a), (b), and (c) respectively. The predicted boiling curves by the modified model, Chen’s model, and Kandlikar’s model are plotted versus the wall temperature in each diagram. The saturated temperatures as well as the ONB points predicted by the modified model are marked by vertical dotted lines.

caption.p: Comparisons of experimental data and model results at 95 °C coolant temperature, 1.5 bar operating pressure: (a) 0.05 m/s velocity, (b) 0.39 m/s velocity, (c) 1.17 m/s velocity
Comparisons of experimental data and model results at 95 °C coolant temperature, 2 bar operating pressure: (a) 0.2 m/s velocity, (b) 0.39 m/s velocity, (c) 1.17 m/s velocity

sec.p: Experimental data for velocities from 0.05 m/s to 1.17 m/s at a fixed coolant temperature of 95 °C and a fixed operating pressure of 1.5 bar are compared with the model results in Fig. 4. It can be seen that with increasing bulk velocity the measured ONB point is typically shifted to a higher wall superheat, and the tendency is accurately predicted by the modified model. Both measurements and predictions indicate that the heat transfer is enhanced as the fluid velocity increases in the low superheat boiling region. However, the measurement points with different velocities converge in the high superheat boiling region, suggesting that fully developed boiling is established. It is noted that only boiling curves predicted by the modified model show similar behaviour to this measured trend, while a discrete tendency of the boiling curves is observed by Chen’s model and Kandlikar’s model as the wall superheat increases.

Experimental data for velocities from 0.2 m/s to 1.17 m/s at a fixed coolant temperature of 95 °C and a fixed operating pressure of 2 bar are compared with model results in Fig. 5. It can be seen from Figs 4 and 5 that a universally higher prediction of the heat flux than the experimental one in the high superheat region is observed by Chen’s model and Kandlikar’s model, while a good agreement is observed by the modified model in both FDB and PDB regions over a wide range of operating conditions. Thus, although the adjustable parameters in the modified model are corrected based on experimental data at a low velocity of 0.05 m/s, as shown in Fig. 4(a), it can be extended to other subcooled boiling conditions at velocities from 0.2 m/s to 1.17 m/s and operating pressures from 1.5 bar to 2 bar with good adaptability, as shown in Figs 4(b) and (c) and Figs 5(a) to (c). It is concluded that the introduction of adjustable parameters in the modified model is an effective approach to predict the subcooled boiling heat flux in some special boiling conditions.

It can be seen from the results that the discrepancy between predicted wall heat fluxes and experimental ones in the highest fluid velocity conditions are observed as the main source of the calculation error for the modified model, as shown in Fig. 4(c) and Fig. 5(c). Since the discrepancy starts completely from the SP region and a decreased tendency is observed in the FDB region as the wall superheat increases, it is indicated that the discrepancy is mainly induced by the calculation error of the convective heat flux. The uncertainty of the k–ε turbulence model and wall function approach in predicting the convective heat flux can be attributed to the following factor.

list-item.p: The adaptability of the turbulence model and wall function. The empirical constants in the k–ε model and wall function were developed on experimental results obtained in special two-dimensional flow and heat transfer conditions with fully developed boundary layers [18], which are different from that inside three-dimensional rectangular tubes with developing thermal boundary layers. This will lead to discrepancies between the predicted results and the practical ones. Besides, since the molecular viscosity is ignored in the standard k–ε model, its use in a comparatively low Reynolds number flow of 5523 at 0.05 m/s would result in additional errors.

The sensitivity of the fluid viscosity to fluid temperature. The near-wall fluid has a higher temperature and lower viscosity than the bulk, which would further affect the heat transfer on the heated wall [19]. This was not taken into account in the wall function approach.

sec.p: The mean deviation defined by Wambsganss et al. [20] was adopted to evaluate the difference between the experimental data and predicted values as follows
where the coefficient N is the number of calculation cases and the subscripts pred and exp relate to the predicted and experimental values respectively.

The mean deviation of each model is listed in Table 2. It can be seen that the mean deviation between the predicted wall heat fluxes and experimental ones in the SP region is maintained at a level of 28.31 per cent by the CFD method, and the prediction by the modified model is found to agree with the experimental results better than the other two boiling models with a lower deviation of 15.45 per cent. Since the uncertainties of the measured heat flux are less than 5 per cent in the convective regime and 2 per cent in the nucleate boiling regime, which is comparatively small [6], it is concluded that a high precision can be obtained by the modified model in predicting the subcooled boiling heat flux over a wide range of operating conditions inside the cooling gallery simulator rig as long as the parameters are accurately corrected.

sec.title: 4 Applications to the IC Engine Cooling Gallery
sec.p: In order to assess the performance of the modified model for practical IC engine applications, a six-cylinder four-stoke water-cooled diesel engine was used for additional investigation.

sec.title: 4.1 Engine case
sec.p: The engine consists of six independent cylinder heads of the same structure. There are no interbore passages in the cylinder cooling gallery, thus both experimental measurements and numerical simulations were performed on cylinder 6. The cylinder head temperature measurements were performed at different coolant temperatures of 80 °C and 100 °C with pressures of 1.42 bar and 1.23 bar in the outlet pipe respectively. Since the maximum temperature of the fluid is lower than the saturation temperature at the minimum pressure in the cooling gallery, it is found that the boiling phenomenon appearing in the engine cooling gallery is verified as subcooled boiling. Twelve K type thermocouples were inserted inside four thermal critical and uncritical areas of the cylinder head. All of the measuring points are located in three planes at the different heights of 9 mm, 6 mm, and 3 mm above the fired surface respectively. The exact locations are visualized in Fig. 6.

caption.p: Locations of the measuring points and computational mesh of the cylinder head and cylinder head cooling gallery

sec.p: A conjugate heat transfer simulation of the cylinder head and cylinder head cooling gallery was utilized to solve this flow/metal conduction problem based on the CFD technology. The geometry was discretized with a hybrid computational mesh between the tetrahedrons and prisms, containing about 1.4 million elements in the cooling gallery domain and 1.2 million of elements in the cylinder head domain, as shown in Fig. 6. The numerical models used in the previous simulation inside the simulator passage were adopted to describe the turbulent flow and heat transfer inside the cooling gallery, while only steady heat conduction equations were utilized to calculate the heat transfer inside the solid domain of the cylinder head.

The coolant is considered as pure water whose physical properties were defined according to the coolant temperature, while the material of the cylinder head is alloy cast iron and its density is 7350 kg/m3, thermal conductivity is 39.2 W/m K, and specific heat is 480 J/kg K. The flow boundary conditions including the flow velocity distribution and turbulent intensity in each gasket hole and the pressure in the outlet hole were derived from the CFD analysis of the whole engine cooling gallery, where the measured flowrate was 23.25 m3/h at the coolant temperature of 80 °C and 16.93 m3/h at the temperature of 100 °C, and the turbulent intensity was set to 4 per cent with a hydraulic diameter of 50.0 mm in the inlet. Thermal boundary conditions on the intake/exhaust port surfaces and the fired surface were derived by a combination of experimental measurements and one-dimensional thermodynamics simulations of this engine performed by the commercial code AVL-BOOST, while thermal boundary conditions on other surfaces were set by experience. The detailed data are listed in Table 3. The metal/fluid interface between the cylinder head and cylinder head cooling gallery served as a coupled wall in the conjugate heat transfer simulation. The thickness of the interface boundary cell in the fluid domain was carefully adjusted to confirm that the corresponding y* was controlled between 30 and 90. The modified model was incorporated by UDF into the CFD package in order to update the local HTC in the superheated wall according to the calculated boiling heat fluxed during iterations. CFD analyses with and without activation of the modified model were performed at different coolant temperatures for a comparison.

caption.p: Thermal boundary conditions of the engine case

sec.p: Since no recommended values of adjustable parameters in the modified model were available to describe the subcooled boiling heat transfer with a water/alloy cast iron combination inside an IC engine cooling gallery, the previous values developed in an asymmetrically heated passage with a fluid/metal combination of water/aluminium alloy were adopted by the modified model.

sec.title: 4.2 Numerical simulation results
sec.p: The predicted superheat distributions on the coolant side of the cylinder head with and without activation of the modified model under each temperature condition are compared in Fig. 7. It can be seen that various degrees of boiling are expected in the zone near the fired side surfaces and exhaust port walls, and the area of the superheated wall is greatly extended as the coolant temperature increases, suggesting that a higher coolant temperature results in a more intense boiling phenomenon inside the cooling gallery. In addition, with the boiling model activated, an obvious decrease in the wall superheat is observed under both coolant temperature conditions. The maximum superheat in the metal surface that is located on the inlet side of the valve bridge passage with a hydraulic diameter of about 40 mm decreases from 88 °C without boiling consideration to 38 °C with boiling consideration at the coolant temperature of 80 °C, while the maximum superheat decreases from 119 °C to 59 °C at the temperature of 100 °C. It is indicated that the local heat transfer is considerably enhanced as the result of the boiling regime. Thus the appearance of the boiling phenomenon in the cooling gallery is intended to protect the metal surface from overheating, and this feature is well captured by the modified model.

caption.p: Predicted superheat distributions on the coolant side of the cylinder head with and without activation of the modified model at different coolant temperatures

sec.p: The comparisons of experimental data and predicted values with and without activation of the modified model at each measuring point are shown in Fig. 8. It can be seen that if boiling is not considered, the discordance between the calculated temperatures and experimental ones is evident, especially in the zone located near the high superheat areas, such as the measuring point 2 at different heights, and it is significantly improved by activating the modified model. However, some discrepancies are still observed at measuring points 3 and 4; even the proposed boiling model is activated, partially because turbulent flow with a strong streamline curvature is found in the area adjacent to the fuel injector seat, where the boundary layer is not adequately resolved by the wall function approach, and partially because the averaged thermal boundary conditions derived from one-dimensional thermodynamic simulations other than the practical three-dimensional distributions on various surfaces were adopted to perform the conjugate heat transfer simulation [21]. Besides, since the precision of the modified model rely greatly on the adjustable parameters, which were developed based on experimental data obtained in cooling gallery simulator passages, the difference of various physical factors such as the wall roughness, metal/fluid combination, passage dimensions, and heating process between subcooled boiling inside the simulator passage and the practical cooling gallery would result in additional errors of the modified model for IC engine applications. Even so, the predicted temperature distribution trend at each measuring point at different heights is basically coincident with the measured one if the proposed boiling model is activated. The mean deviation obtained by the modified model is 5.8 per cent, which is evidently lower than that without boiling consideration of 11.3 per cent. Thus the computational error is effectively reduced due to the incorporation of the modified model in CFD analyses.

caption.p: Comparisons of experimental data and predicted values with and without activation of the modified model at each point

sec.p: It is worth mentioning that a further increase in the wall superheat will lead to a transition from the nucleate boiling mode to the film boiling mode, resulting in a drastic decrease of the HTC and a sharp increase of the temperature in the heated wall, which is strictly prevented in the development of reliable engine cooling systems, but this feature is not taken into account in the proposed model. Thus, more studies should be conducted to improve the ability of the modified model to predict the transition point from nucleate to film boiling for IC engine applications.

sec.title: 5 Conclusions
sec.p: In the present paper, a modified division description model is proposed within the CFD framework, where a pool boiling correlation with adjustable parameters is adopted to predict the boiling heat flux in the FDB region, while an exponential function based on the temperature difference between the wall and the bulk liquid is utilized to describe the boiling curve in the PDB region. Since no geometry-dependent parameters are required by the modified model, it can be incorporated into a CFD package to predict the flow boiling heat transfer in geometrically complex cooling galleries of IC engines.

The comparisons between predictions by different boiling models and experimental data obtained in a cooling gallery simulator passage indicate that a higher precision can be obtained by the modified model in predicting the boiling heat flux over a wide range of operating conditions as long as the parameters are accurately corrected. Further, experimental measurements and numerical simulations were performed on a practical IC engine under different coolant temperature conditions. The results show that a higher coolant temperature results in a more intense boiling phenomenon inside the cooling gallery and the computational error is effectively reduced due to the incorporation of the modified model in CFD analyses.

However, in order to realize reasonable control of the boiling intensity inside the engine cooling galleries, more studies should be conducted to improve the ability of the modified model to predict the transition point from the nucleate to film boiling for IC engine applications.

sec.title: Subscripts

boil nucleate boiling heat transfer
conv convective heat transfer
exp experimental
FDB fully developed boiling
g gas
